title: Vue.js 3.0 "One Piece" release
description: "The 3.0 release represents over 2 years of development efforts, featuring 30+ RFCs, 2,600+ commits, 628 pull requests from 99 contributors, plus tremendous amount of development and documentation work outside of the core repo."

title: ECMAScript 2020
description: Introduction of BigInt for arbitrary-sized integers, new null coalescing syntax, and a name which always refers to the global object.

title: SpaceX Dragon 2 with JavaScript UI in space
description: Sofian Hnaide said in AMA raddit tread, "Yes we use Chromium and we do use a reactive library that we developed in house."

title: WebStorm turns 10
description: The WebStorm team celebrates the tenth WebStorm's birthday, working on the new IDE version and trying to get to used to the new "working from home" reality.

title: Deno 1.0 released
description: Deno finally makes it to public with it's first release. It's still not clear whether it's going to become the next big thing but the hopes are high.

title: WebAssembly 1.0 to be the fourth language to run natively in browsers
description: The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) announces that the WebAssembly Core Specification is now an official web standard. Following HTML, CSS and JavaScript, WebAssembly thus officially becomes the fourth language to run natively in browsers.

title: Optional Chaining and Nullish Coalescing
description: Both proposals were moved to stage 4. Syntax was extended with two new operators ?. and ?? which helps to write more safe code

title: ECMAScript 2019
description: New features include Array.prototype.flat, Array.prototype.flatMap, changes to Array.sort and Object.fromEntries.

title: Svelte 3 released
description:
The framework gets a major update, Svelte 3 and starts gaining popularity. Many developers try to understand why this update is important and share their thoughts with the community.

"Compiler frameworks uncover new horizons for the future of the web. Are we heading towards a decline of front-end frameworks as we know them today to make way for compilers? When will this happen? How? Who will be the main actors? It's far too early to say, all this will take time, but one thing is sure, Svelte contributes strongly to this new momentum and makes the web move forward."

title: React hooks announcement
description: Sophie Alpert, Dan Abramov, and Ryan Florence defined problem with wrapper hell, huge components and confusing classes and showed React hooks.

title: ECMAScript 2018
description: Rest/spread operator for object literals, asynchronous iteration and additions to RegExp.

title: Ryan Dahl presents the prototype of Deno
description: Ryan Dahl, the creator of Node.js, gives a talk at JSConf EU 2018 and introduces Deno, a new runtime for JavaScript and TypeScript. The talk was called 10 Things I Regret About Node.js and is still available on YouTube.

title: ECMAScript 2017
description: Improvements include Object.values, Object.entries and Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors functions for easier object manipulation, async/await constructions which use generators and promises as well as concurrency and atomic features.

title: npm v5.0.0 released with package-lock.json
description: "A new, standardised lockfile feature meant for cross-package-manager compatibility (package-lock.json), and a new format and semantics for shrinkwrap"

title: Prettier 1.0 released
description:
Christopher Chedeau and James Long publish a blog post about Prettier 1.0 release.

"We officially announced prettier over two months ago as a way to solve the problem of wasting time formatting your code. It started as an experiment but it clearly resonated with a lot of people, amassing ~7000 GitHub stars and over 100,000 monthly npm downloads in just two months."

title: Temporal proposal initial commit
description: Maggie Johnson-Pint started motivation with, "Date has been a long time pain point in ECMAScript. This proposes 'temporal', a built in module that brings a DateTime API similar to Java 8's to the ECMAScript language."

title: Nest.js available on npm
description: Kamil Mysliwiec created Node.js framework with architecture is heavily inspired by Angular

title: Version 1 of Svelte
description: Rich Harris publishes the article Frameworks without the framework: why didn't we think of this sooner? and introduces Svelte.js, another JavaScript framework.

title: Yarn: a new package manager for JavaScript
Angular was born
description: The same team that built AngularJS completely rewrites it and introduces Angular 2, written in TypeScript. At this point, quite a few teams started to turn their back on AngularJS for libraries like React. Some developers even wrote break-up letters to their once beloved framework.

title: async/await
description: Async Functions proposal was moved to stage 4

title: ECMAScript 2016 finalized
description: This update got such features as async and await keywords for asynchronous programming, block-scoping of variables and functions, destructing patters of variables, among many others.

title: First commits to TC39 proposals repository
description: The repository contains all actual information about stages of proposals to ECMAScript

title: GraphQL: a data query language
description: Facebook introduces GraphQL, a query language for APIs and a runtime for fulfilling those queries with existing data, which they had already been using for three years internally back then.

title: Node.js and io.js combined into single codebase
npm v3.0.0 release with flat dependencies
description:
"Flat, flat, flat!
Your dependencies will now be installed maximally flat. Insofar as is possible, all of your dependencies, and their dependencies, and THEIR dependencies will be installed in your project's node_modules folder with no nesting. You'll only see modules nested underneath one another when two (or more) modules have conflicting dependencies."

title: Redux initial release
description:
Redux was created by Dan Abramov and Andrew Clark. Dan began writing the first Redux implementation while preparing for a conference talk at React Europe.

Dan remarks, "I was trying to make a proof of concept of Flux where I could change the logic. And it would let me time travel. And it would let me reapply the future actions on the code change."

title: ES2015, big ECMAScript update
description:
The 6th edition, initially known as ECMAScript 6 was later renamed to ECMAScript 2015, or ES2015. This big update included arrow function expressions, let and const keywords, class declaration, promises, generators and many other improvements.

Starting from this edition, ECMAScript would also get regular updates each year.

title: NativeScript 1.0.0 released
description: Version 1 of NativeScript, an open-source framework that allows you to write native apps for Android, iOS and Windows Phone using JavaScript, has become available.

title: VS Code released
description: Microsoft announces Visual Studio Code, a new member of the Visual Studio family, at its annual conference Build. The new code editor was built using the Electron framework.

title: io.js: Node.js split in two
description: The part of the Node.js team, who were unhappy with the stewardship of Node's official sponsor, Joyent, forked the Node.js project and created their own version of it called io.js. The main differences included proper semver and the updated V8 engine with ES6 features. In the long run, they hoped that both projects would be merged back together and that it would help the JavaScript community move forward.

title: First commit to Babel.js
description: Sebastian McKenzie started project with '6to5' name above acornjs parser for transpiling new version of ECMAScript for old browsers.

title: Atom, text editor built on Electron
Vue.js released by Evan You
description: "I figured, what if I could just extract the part that I really liked about Angular and build something really lightweight without all the extra concepts involved? I was also curious as to how its internal implementation worked. I started this experiment just trying to replicate this minimal feature set, like declarative data binding. That was basically how Vue started."

title: PostCSS was released
description: Andrey Sitnik create PostCSS for replacing Rework project in Autoprefixer

title: First commit in core-js repository
description: Denis Pushkarev started the project for system polyfilling new features of JavaScript.

title: GitHub introduces Electron
description: GitHub develops Atom Shell, a framework that would be later renamed to Electron. The goal behind this was to "create a straightforward framework that would allow people to use web technologies to build cross-platform desktop apps with all of the native trimmings."

title: First ESLint release
description: Both JSLint and JSHint were lacking the ability to create additional rules for code quality and coding style. After contributing to JSHint, Nicholas C. Zakas decided to create a new linting tool where all rules are configurable, and additional rules can be defined or loaded at run-time.

title: The beginning of React Native's story
description: React Native started as a hackathon project in the summer of 2013.

title: React gets open sourced
description:
Tom Occhino and Jordan Walke introduce React at JSConf US 2013. React becomes an open-source project.

The audience at the conference was skeptical. Some people thought that React was a huge step backward. This happened as mostly "early adopters" and "early majority" attended this conference, while React was targeted at "innovators".

title: asm.js in Firefox Nightly
description: asm.js, a subset of JavaScript later superseded by WebAssembly, was announced to be shipped with Firefox 22.

title: Autoprefixer initial commit
description: Andrey Sitnik created plugin for Rework project for for automatically adding vendor prefixes in CSS code.

title: TypeScript tooling starts to catch up
description: WebStorm was among the first cross-platform IDEs to get support for TypeScript.

title: ECMAScript Internationalization API Specification 1st Edition
description:
"The ECMAScript Internationalization API provides key language-sensitive functionality as a complement to the ECMAScript Language Specification, 5.1 edition or successor. Its functionality has been selected from that of well-established internationalization APIs such as those of the Internationalization Components for Unicode (ICU) library, of the .NET framework, or of the Java platform.

The API was developed by an ad-hoc group established by Ecma TC 39 in September 2010 based on a proposal by Nebojša Ćirić and Jungshik Shin."

title: Promises/A+ specification initial commit
description: An open standard for sound, interoperable JavaScript promises—by implementers, for implementers.

title: TypeScript made public
description:
After 2 years of internal development, Microsoft introduces a JavaScript superset called TypedScript. They developed TypeScript in at attempt to help use JavaScript for large-scale development.

The first impressions of TypeScript were controversial. For example, Miguel de Icaza highlighted quite a few pros but also raised concerns about the lack of support for TypeScript in tooling, apart from Microsoft Visual Studio.

title: Bower initial release
description: Twitter made the package manager for the web. Bower tried to build flat dependency tree.

title: Meteor officially launched
description: Initially introduced under the name Skybreak, Meteor, a framework and application server for building websites in JavaScript, was officially soft-launched.

title: webpack module bundler
description: webpack, a new static module bundler for JavaScript applications, is introduced.

title: Dart unveiled
description: Lars Bak and Gilad Bracha from Google give a talk at GOTO Aarhus and present a new programming language called Dart.

title: An early prototype of React
description: Jordan Walke starts working on FaxJS, the early prototype of React.

title: WebKit Remote Debugging
description: WebKit Remote Debugging opened new era for debugging mobile browsers. In future it'll transform to Chrome DevTools Protocol.

title: The first commit of Ember.js
description: The first commit to the repository that would become Ember.js happened on April 30th, 2011. About two and a half years later, the Ember.js core team would announce the release of Ember 1.0.

title: IE6 Countdown
description: Microsoft launches a website called IE6 Countdown which would show the usage of Internet Explorer 6 in the world to motivate people to upgrade.

title: Moment.js release
description: Tim Wood released one of the popular library for working with dates.

title: rx first publication on npm
description: Set of libraries to compose asynchronous and event-based programs using observable collections.

title: AngularJS released
description: AngularJS was originally developed in 2009 by Miško Hevery

title: Backbone.js released
description: Jeremy Ashkenas released Backbone.js which was designed specifically for building single-page apps with JavaScript.

title: WebStorm 1.0, a new JavaScript IDE by JetBrains
description:
Previously known under its working name Web IDE, WebStorm 1.0 was released with support for HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Support for these technologies had been available within IntelliJ IDEA, another IDE by JetBrains, starting from 2005, but now developers got a chance to use a dedicated tool for JavaScript development.

title: Test262: ECMAScript Test Suite initial contribution
description: Test262 is the implementation conformance test suite for the latest drafts (or most recent published edition) of the following Ecma specifications: ECMA-262, ECMA-402, ECMA-404

title: npm was born
description:
Isaac Schlueter invents npm, a brand-new package manager for JavaScript.

"Back in 2009, after too long without a vacation, I quit my job, in hopes of discovering what happens when I untether my creativity.

What happened is I wrote a package manager.

I created npm with the goal of sharing modules in a tiny group of nerdy weirdos who'd decided to write web servers in JavaScript. From that niche beginning, npm grew, slowly but surely, the background project I'd greedily steal away time for."

title: Initial commit of CoffeeScript
description:
On December 14, 2009, Jeremy Ashkenas commits a bunch of files to GitHub with the message: "initial commit of the mystery language". Drawing inspiration from Python, Ruby, and some other languages, he started working on a new programming language that compiles into JavaScript called CoffeeScript.

Ashkenas is also known as the creator of two JavaScript libraries - Underscore.js and Backbone.js.

title: End of dark times for ECMAScript
description: With the version 3.1 used as a starting point, ECMAScript finally gets revamped after a very long break. The new fifth version includes such important features as strict mode, getters and setters, JSON support, and many others.

title: The rise of Node.js
description: Ryan Dahl gives a talk at JSConf 2009 and introduces Node.js, a JavaScript runtime built on top of Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. From now on, JavaScript developers can build their entire web application stack with a single programming language - the JavaScript Everywhere paradigm becomes a reality.

title: Google Closure Compiler release
description: Google Closure Compiler still stay one of the best JavaScript code minifier with amazing dead code elimination ability

title: RequireJS module loader
description: The primordial parts of the RequireJS loader started to take form in September 2009, with many releases through October 2011, when 1.0 was introduced.

title: Work on Express.js started
description: TJ Holowaychuk makes the initial commit to the repository called expressjs, which would later become a home for a popular Node.js framework.

title: PhoneGap created
description: PhoneGap brings HTML5 and JavaScript to mobile applications in iOS and Android, creating the cross-platform application category.

title: CommonJS project started
description: Kevin Dangoon sets up a new ServerJS group trying to standardize the module ecosystem for JavaScript outside of the web browser. The project was later renamed to CommonJS.

title: Google Chrome: a fresh take on the browser
description: To "help drive innovation on the web", Google launches the beta version of Google Chrome, along with a new JavaScript engine, V8. They accompanied the announcement by this comic book.

title: JavaScript: The Good Parts book release
description: One of the most popular book about JavaScript. It was written by Douglas Crockford

title: Ext JS 1.0 released
description: The version 1.0 of Ext JS, a framework for building interactive cross-platform web applications with Ajax, DHTML and DOM, was released.

title: Steve Jobs announced iPhone without support Adobe Flash Player
description: With iPhone Steve presented iPhone version of Safari browser. Supporting for Adobe Flash Player never has been added for Safari on iPhone. It has driven process of HTML5 standardization.

title: Microsoft restarts IE development
description: Internet Explorer gets the first major update since 2001.

title: Google Web Toolkit release
description: One of the first toolchains for compiling Java to JavaScript.

title: YUI Library release
description: YUI contained a lot of components and one of the first minifiers of JavaScript code: YUI Compressor.

title: Initial release of jQuery
description: John Resig makes the initial release of jQuery, a JavaScript library that makes it easier to navigate the HTML DOM and manipulate it.

title: Dojo Toolkit 0.1
description: Alex Russell, Dylan Schiemann, David Schontzler, and some other folks release the 0.1 version of Dojo, a JavaScript toolkit designed to ease the development of cross-platform, Ajax-based applications and web sites. The first stable version is yet to come in 2007.

title: Apple open sources WebKit
description: Apple announces the immediate availability of the WebKit Open Source Project, their fork of KHTML.

title: Adobe Photoshop CS2 release with JavaScript as one of scripting languages
description: "All of the Adobe Creative Suite 2 applications, including Adobe Photoshop CS2, use ExtendScript, Adobe’s extended implementation of JavaScript. ExtendScript files are distinguished by the .jsx extension. ExtendScript offers all standard JavaScript features, plus additional features and utilities"

title: Prototype.js created
description: Prototype, a JavaScript framework that aims to ease the development of dynamic web applications, was made available. The framework offered extensive Ajax support, higher-order programming constructs, and easy DOM manipulation.

title: Jesse James Garrett coins the term Ajax
description: Jesse introduces the new term in an article titled Ajax: A New Approach to Web Applications, based on techniques used on Google pages.

title: The rise of MDN
description: Deb Richardson joins Mozilla Corporation and launches the initial Mozilla Developer Network in March 2005.

title: WHATWG Formation
description: The WHATWG was founded by individuals from Apple Inc., the Mozilla Foundation and Opera Software, leading Web browser vendors in response to the slow development of W3C.

title: Beta release of Gmail
description: Google publicly announces Gmail, starting the Ajax (even though the term wasn't coined yet) and web application era. Its release on April 1 made some people think that the announcement was a prank.

title: Dark times for ECMAScript
description: After months of hard work on the new update to ECMAScript, the fourth edition was abandoned in June, 2003. Some of the features proposed for that edition have never made it to the standard.

title: Apple introduces Safari and WebKit
description: Giving a speech at Macworld Expo, Steve Jobs unveils a new Macintosh browser named Safari. The browser was based on Apple's internal fork of the KHTML rendering engine, called WebKit.

title: Mozilla Firefox released
description: Internet Explorer, which has been dominating the market of web browsers since early 2000s, is about to start losing a part of its market share to a new web browser, Mozilla Firefox.

title: JSLint
description: JSLint by Douglas Crockford is considered by some to be the first JavaScript syntax checker. It has since inspired various other tools.

title: Internet Explorer 6 made available
description: This would become the last major update to this browser for the next 5 years. Despite dominating the market share, this version of Internet Explorer was widely criticized for its security issues and lack of support for modern web standards. It even got into some of the "worst tech products of all time" lists, being labeled as "the least secure software on the planet."

title: The first JSON message was sent
Opera browser goes free
description: Opera, the "third force in the browser wars", was made available for free download from December 6, 2000, with the launch of Opera 5.0.

title: KHTML rewritten
description: KHTML, a browser engine developed by the KDE project and the ancestor of WebKit, was included in KDE 2.0.

title: Flash Player 5 released with ActionScript
description: Flash Player 5 included the first version of ActionScript. This version was influenced by JavaScript and the ECMA-262 standard and supported the standard's object model and many of its core data types.

title: XSS mentioned in CERT®
description: XSS attacks enable attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Almost all popular web services had XSS problems.

title: ECMAScript 3 released
description: The new version gets regular expressions, try/catch exception handling, better error handling, and some other important enhancements.

title: JSDoc debut
description: An early example using a Javadoc-like syntax to document JavaScript was released in 1999 with the Netscape/Mozilla project Rhino, a JavaScript runtime system written in Java. The project included a toy "JSDoc" HTML generator as an example of its JavaScript capabilities.

title: First steps to Ajax
description: With Internet Explorer 5.0, Microsoft releases the first version of XMLHttpRequest (XHR), an API for transferring data between a web browser and a web server.

title: Updates to ECMAScript 1
description: Some minor editorial changes to the ECMAScript 1 specification were made to keep it fully aligned with ISO/IEC 16262 international standard.

title: Mozilla Project created
description: Netscape open sources its browser suite, which leads to the creation of the Mozilla Project.

title: The first edition of ECMA-262 published
description: With the first edition of ECMAScript, browser vendors, among the others, get a consistent set of guidelines for implementing the JavaScript language.

title: CSS1 specifications by W3C
description: The World Wide Web Consortium introduces the document specifying level 1 of the Cascading Style Sheet mechanism.

title: The beginning of JavaScript standardization
description: Netscape realizes that JavaScript needs to be standardized and submits a proposal to ECMA International.

title: JavaScript gets its first dialect
description: Internet Explorer, the recently introduced browser by Microsoft, gets its own, reverse-engineered alternative to JavaScript and names it JScript. Two almost identical languages, JScript and JavaScript, existed at this time.

title: JavaScript: The Definitive Guide, Beta Version book release
description: David Flanagan wrote one of the first book about JavaScript

title: Netscape and Sun Microsystems announce JavaScript
description: In an attempt to make web pages dynamic, Brendan Eich from Netscape starts working on a new scripting language. The first version of this language was developed in ten days and called Mocha. Later it was renamed to LiveScript and finally to JavaScript.
